thinking.disposable_income: Douglas has relatively low disposable income with median household income of $43,528 and 54.3% of households making less than $50k annually. This suggests high sensitivity to costs from fares, fees, and taxes.
thinking.discretionary_consumption: With high percentage of low-income households and per capita income of $35,007, discretionary spending is limited. Additional transportation costs would significantly impact household budgets.
thinking.accessibility: 44.4% of households have no vehicle, and 26.4% use transit for commuting. The community heavily relies on public transit, while 40.3% drive alone. Current mean commute time is 31.8 minutes.
thinking.decision_rationale: 1. Given low incomes, prioritize low transit fares and taxes to maintain affordability. 2. High transit dependency means better transit service is important. 3. Large car-free population benefits from improved transit times. 4. Some driving fee acceptable to fund transit improvements since 45.7% own cars. 5. Balance between transit improvement and cost burden leads to moderate policy combinations.
